title: Verification of Ohm's Law
objective: To verify Ohm's Law and determine the resistance of a given wire.
theory:
Ohm's Law states that the current (I) flowing through a conductor is directly proportional to the potential difference (V) across its ends, provided the physical conditions (temperature, etc.) remain constant.

V ∝ I  =>  V = IR

Where R is the constant of proportionality called resistance. A graph of V (y-axis) versus I (x-axis) is a straight line passing through the origin, and its slope gives the resistance R.

procedure.instruction: Draw the circuit diagram showing the battery, ammeter, voltmeter, rheostat, and resistance wire connected properly.
Connect the components according to the circuit diagram. Ensure the ammeter is in series and the voltmeter is in parallel with the resistance wire.
Insert the key and adjust the rheostat to obtain a small reading in the ammeter and voltmeter.
Record the ammeter reading (I) and the corresponding voltmeter reading (V).
Adjust the rheostat to get different values of current and voltage, recording at least 5-6 sets of readings.
Plot a graph of V versus I.

precautions.instruction: Connections should be tight and clean.
The key should be inserted only while taking readings to avoid heating of the wire.
The range of ammeter and voltmeter should be chosen appropriately.

defaultResult.summary: The graph of V versus I is a straight line passing through the origin, verifying Ohm's Law.
defaultResult.calculation: Slope of V-I graph = (V2 - V1) / (I2 - I1) = R (Resistance in Ohms).

safetyNotes: Do not touch the resistance wire while current is flowing as it may get hot.

title: Measurement with Vernier Caliper
objective: To measure the diameter and length of a small cylinder using a Vernier Caliper and calculate its volume.
theory:
The Vernier Caliper is a precision instrument used to measure internal and external dimensions. The total reading is given by:

Total Reading (TR) = Main Scale Reading (MSR) + (Vernier Scale Reading (VSR) × Least Count (LC))

Least Count (LC) = 1 MSD - 1 VSD (typically 0.01 cm).

procedure.instruction: Determine the least count of the Vernier Caliper.
Check for zero error. If present, note it down to correct the final reading.
Place the cylinder between the lower jaws to measure the diameter. Tighten the screw gently.
Note the MSR and VSR. Calculate the total reading.
Repeat the measurement at different positions to get an average diameter.
Similarly, measure the length of the cylinder using the lower jaws.

precautions.instruction: Do not apply excessive pressure on the jaws.
Take readings at different positions to account for irregularities.

defaultResult.summary: The dimensions of the cylinder are measured accurately.
defaultResult.calculation: Volume V = πr²h, where r = diameter/2 and h = length.

safetyNotes: Handle the instrument with care to avoid damaging the jaws.

title: Measurement with Screw Gauge
objective: To measure the diameter of a given wire using a Screw Gauge.
theory:
A Screw Gauge is used for measuring small dimensions with high precision. The linear distance moved by the screw in one complete rotation is the pitch.

Least Count (LC) = Pitch / Total number of divisions on circular scale (typically 0.001 cm or 0.01 mm).

Total Reading = PSR + (CSR × LC).

procedure.instruction: Determine the pitch and least count of the screw gauge.
Check for zero error by bringing the stud and spindle in contact.
Place the wire between the stud and spindle.
Rotate the ratchet until it clicks to ensure uniform pressure.
Note the Pitch Scale Reading (PSR) and Circular Scale Reading (CSR).
Repeat at different points along the wire.

precautions.instruction: Rotate the screw only by the ratchet to avoid overtightening.
Take measurements in mutually perpendicular directions at each point to check for circularity.

defaultResult.summary: The diameter of the wire is determined with high precision.
defaultResult.calculation: Average Diameter D = Mean of corrected readings.

title: Simple Pendulum
objective: To determine the acceleration due to gravity (g) using a simple pendulum.
theory:
For small amplitudes, the time period (T) of a simple pendulum of length (L) is given by:

T = 2π √(L/g)

Squaring both sides: T² = (4π²/g) * L

Therefore, g = 4π² * (L/T²). A graph of L vs T² is a straight line.

procedure.instruction: Tie the metallic bob to one end of the thread and pass the other end through the split cork clamped to the stand.
Measure the effective length L (distance from the point of suspension to the center of the bob).
Displace the bob slightly to one side and release it to oscillate in a vertical plane.
Measure the time for 20 oscillations using a stopwatch.
Calculate the time period T = Time for 20 oscillations / 20.
Repeat for different lengths (e.g., 80cm, 90cm, 100cm).
Plot a graph of L versus T².

precautions.instruction: The amplitude of oscillation should be small.
The pendulum should oscillate in a vertical plane without spinning.
Fan should be switched off to minimize air resistance.

defaultResult.summary: The value of g is calculated from the slope of the L-T² graph.
defaultResult.calculation: g = 4π² * Slope, where Slope = ΔL / ΔT².

title: Focal Length of Convex Lens
objective: To find the focal length of a convex lens by plotting graphs between u and v.
theory:
The lens formula is given by:

1/f = 1/v - 1/u

Where f is the focal length, u is the object distance, and v is the image distance. By measuring v for different values of u, f can be determined.

procedure.instruction: Determine the approximate focal length by focusing a distant object on a screen.
Mount the lens and needles on the optical bench uprights.
Place the object needle at a distance greater than f (between f and 2f or beyond 2f).
Adjust the image needle to remove parallax between the tip of the object needle's image and the tip of the image needle.
Measure the object distance (u) and image distance (v).
Repeat for different object positions.

precautions.instruction: Tips of the needles and the optical center of the lens should be at the same height.

defaultResult.summary: The focal length is determined from the observations.
defaultResult.calculation: f = uv / (u+v) (using sign convention, usually u is -ve, v is +ve for real image).

title: Hooke's Law
objective: To determine the spring constant of a helical spring by plotting a graph between load and extension.
theory:
Hooke's Law states that within the elastic limit, the extension (x) produced in a spring is directly proportional to the applied load (F).

F = kx

Where k is the spring constant (force constant). The slope of the Load (F) vs Extension (x) graph gives k.

procedure.instruction: Suspend the spring from a rigid support and attach a pointer and weight hanger.
Note the initial reading of the pointer on the scale with the dead load (hanger).
Add weights in steps (e.g., 50g) and note the reading for each weight.
Remove weights one by one and note the readings again (unloading).
Calculate the extension x for each load.
Plot a graph of Load (mg) vs Extension (x).

precautions.instruction: Do not load the spring beyond its elastic limit.
Wait for the spring to stop oscillating before taking readings.

defaultResult.summary: The graph is a straight line, verifying Hooke's Law.
defaultResult.calculation: Spring constant k = Slope of F-x graph = ΔF / Δx (N/m).

safetyNotes: Keep feet away from below the weights in case they fall.
